data.title: The Fallout Of U.S.-Iran Round Two
data.description:
After months of the U.S. and Iran posturing—both politically and militarily—in the Persian Gulf, and following a previous attack on its nuclear program and air defenses in June, the U.S. and Israel have conducted another set of strikes. This time, the targets were much more numerous and varied.

It is unclear if more are to come, as the events are still unfolding.

This is what escalation looks like.

Iran escalated in tow, firing missiles at U.S. bases across the Middle East. Some were intercepted, with their intended targets either unknown or, more likely, undisclosed to the public at this time.

President Trump sent a message to the public following the attacks, which included addressing the Iranian people:

to the...people of Iran, I say tonight that the hour of your freedom is at hand...When we are finished, take over your government. It will be yours to take. This will be probably your only chance for generations.

For many years, you have asked for America's help...Now you have a president who is giving you what you want. So let's see how you respond. America is backing you with overwhelming strength and devastating force. Now is the time to seize control of your destiny, and to unleash the prosperous and glorious future that is close within your reach. This is the moment for action. Do not let it pass.

Reporting out of the Islamic Republic is sparse, since the government has shut down Internet access in the country (people are smuggling in Starlink nodes to counteract this), so it's unclear how the people are responding at this time. The unrest in the months leading up to this strike has been so widespread that it has been called a “2nd Iranian Revolution.” Time will tell how that will unfold.

For now, that's the necessary get-you-up-to-speed part. Now, let's talk about consequences.

Note: I’m mindful of the heavy human and political weight of current events, but for the purpose of this piece, I’m keeping the focus strictly on the potential market impacts.

The Speculators Are Still Driving Oil

I warned folks about oil in January, when this saga really started to get news coverage. Oil has been bought up on speculation that this event would cause the closure of key oil passageways. Increasingly YTD, the movement in the price of oil has been concentrated in speculation around geopolitical risk.

At the time, I was worried that there would not be another escalatory event, and oil would sell off as tensions cooled. Speculators have won, as oil surged higher following reports that Iran is indeed closing the Strait of Hormuz. This chokepoint is incredibly important because Kuwaiti, Bahraini, Qatari, Emirati, and Saudi oil all flow through there to large extents.

A closure of the strait would halt ~20% of the world's daily oil supply.

If this stoppage holds and is adhered to through the weekend, it could mean a spiral of speculators pouring into oil. This is stay-away territory, because the price of oil could go parabolic in response. It is still moderate right now, likely because the market is pricing in a return to normal with the strait within the next day.

It looks like investors are pricing in tanker delays and additional geopolitical risk, not a full closure of the straits just yet.

There is already evidence of ships turning around. Ship tracking sites are showing oil tankers making U-turns to avoid the strait. It is unclear if this ship, and others like it that are making similar maneuvers, are leaving due to the strait's closure or for their safety to avoid crossfire during a conflict. Many tankers may have insurance carriers that demanded they avoid the strait as news of strikes broke out, and so they turned around even if the Iranian authorities didn't cause it.

For now, this is still in the fog of war information-wise, and so it's unclear how much further oil could go. It will depend on the depth of escalation moving forward and what is really going on with passage through the strait.

The worse this conflict gets, the higher oil is likely to go, and I expect that to hold true until there is some resolution about the strait. That doesn't mean that there has to be resolution about Iran or their government. The U.S. breaking their control of the strait and allowing transit could cause oil to come back down quickly.

OPEC+ Still Has A Say

There is a point to note here that the price of oil was beaten down all last year, and so even though it has jumped on this recent speculation, its absolute levels are still fairly low to recent history.

One of the levers of the oil market is OPEC+, which Iran is part of but whose controlling members Iran just shot missiles at. Sure, the targets were American bases, but I cannot imagine that there is a single Gulf monarchy that is happy with Iran right now.

The next meeting is March 1st, and I imagine that they will work on making sure that OPEC+ oil is allowed through the strait. Whether that is achievable or not is unclear, so for now, all we can do is speculate.

Perhaps a solution is reached where Iran allows partial passage for OPEC+ tankers, but not for U.S. or EU-flagged vessels. Again, speculation.

Another thing that they will decide is their target output levels. They could hike production again to use volume to offset the price hikes. OPEC+ has been working on creating an oil glut over the last year, and while they slowed production recently, it is common for them to change direction quickly in response to events like these. This is especially poignant for the Gulf monarchies because they are responding to what is happening on their doorstep this time around, unlike with Venezuela.

Stocks Will Shake It Off

We don't buy any oil from Iran, and the U.S. doesn't import much from the affected countries. In fact, this closure really hurts China and India more than anyone else, although South Korea and Japan will also need to find a new supply if the straits really are closed.

The U.S. economy is unlikely to be affected by this major economic consequence of escalation with Iran. Stocks may sell off as fear sets in for traders and speculators. For the record, I do not believe we will go to war with Iran, but I do not control what narratives the market puts weight in.

It behooves us to remember that markets are forward-looking. They react to today's news, but it becomes priced in quickly, and tomorrow's news quickly takes over.

A friend said it best to me when we were discussing the potential of the U.S. attacking Iran again earlier this week:

They always do it on a Friday. That way, the markets can fall over the weekend. By Monday's open, there's been two news cycles. That's a lot of time for other stories to take over.

And history shows us the truth in this. Past wars have not been long-term negative catalysts for markets. They don't always even cause sell-offs.

Gold Wins the Day, Of Course

It was no surprise to see gold hit >$5,400 after the news dropped of escalation between the U.S. and Iran. Gold has been particularly responsive to geopolitical tensions since 2022, replacing the role of the U.S. dollar as the ultimate safe haven from chaos.

Imagine telling an investor in the 00s that traders would run to treasury duration to avoid geopolitical risk. They worry about what sovereigns are doing, so they buy sovereign debt? Mind-blowing.

Not the part about gold, though—that checks out for most people. Geopolitical risk invites investors to load up on an asset that sovereigns don't outright control.

Through last year, geopolitical risk was a strong driver for gold's returns. This is similar to oil, and so similar risks should be considered—a conclusion of the tensions could mean a sell-off is in store. Gold in particular is in a much more precarious position than oil since its producers are not putting it in a glut.

We can see just how much of a drag momentum has been, and I expect it to continue to be, as long-term holders realize their gains after the best year for gold in decades.

If you want to know more about my gold convictions, take a look at my most recent gold-focused article, “Gold Isn't Near a Peak.” It's crazy to think that the article was written just a month ago, and gold is up ~15% since.

Conclusion

Ultimately, the jury is still out on how things will unfold in Iran. The U.S. has not given any signals if more attacks are imminent, and it's unclear if or for how long Iran intends to try to close the Strait of Hormuz. That will be a determining factor for how markets react.

Oil is bid up on speculation, and a full closure, which would likely include direct U.S. intervention in the area, could cause oil to spike. Beware if you are trading oil or oil-related ETFs.

I don't expect too much pain to bleed over into the U.S. economy even if oil is stopped, as we do not import much from the Persian Gulf. The stock market may react negatively at first, but time will heal things, as other news cycles will begin to factor in. This conflict does not stop the next earnings call from happening, and so, for now, I am not worried about much movement in indexes, although individual firms with exposure to the conflict area are another story.

Gold is the key winner of rising geopolitical tensions in our current market, and I expect precious metals across the board to benefit regardless of the outcome in Iran.

Crises and conflicts like this are a good reminder that position sizing is more important than security selection. It is very difficult to time these events and to trade them, so ensuring that your risk exposure is appropriate is critical for your portfolio when bombs start flying—and they are flying.

I hope for peace.

Thanks for reading.

data.title: The U.S.-Iran War: Phase One
data.description:
The Operation Epic Fury

The US and Israel staged a major attack on Iran on Saturday morning, local time. Based on President Trump's statement, the mission of Operation Epic Fury seems to be regime change in Iran.

The initial attacks were on the offices of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and the locations of other key Iranian political and military leaders.

Iran immediately retaliated by launching strikes on US military bases in the region and Israel.

Note: I’m mindful of the heavy human and political weight of current events, but for the purpose of this piece, I’m keeping the focus strictly on the market and economic impacts.

The big picture

The immediate justification for Operation Fury is related to Iran's nuclear program. A nuclear Iran is an existential threat to Israel, and President Trump was clear that Iran can never have a nuclear weapon. The negotiations leading to the attack failed, as Iran refused to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

However, there is also a big-picture macro view.

Specifically, we are in the process of global fragmentation and polarization, with the unfolding collapse of the post-WWII world order. The main blocks are emerging, the US-led block and the China-led block, with a possibility of a third EU-led block.

The China-led bloc includes Russia, North Korea, and Iran. Venezuela was part of this block until the Maduro capture. It seems like Iran is next to collapse - and for this, it's important to have the regime change in Iran where the new regime must be US-friendly.

The current process of polarization is complicated by the fact that China has a global monopoly on rare earths, which are crucial for advanced tech and military purposes.

At the same time, China imports 70-75% of the energy it consumes, and Iran is one of the top energy suppliers to China. China also imported oil from Venezuela. Thus, by controlling the oil supplies from Iran and Venezuela, the US is gaining leverage over China on energy security.

This is all happening in advance of Trump's visit to China at the end of March. Trump and Xi will likely discuss the extension of the temporary truce on rare materials export ban, which is set to expire in November.

What happens next in Iran?

Operation Epic Fury is very risky. The plan assumes that the regime change can be done by the Iranian people and that the Iranian security forces will surrender.

The US-Israeli strikes at this time have a mission of regime change led by a rebellion from within. At this point we don't have any information about internal rebellion against the leadership from the general population or the security forces.

At this point, Operation Epic Fury is not targeting the Iranian nuclear infrastructure or energy infrastructure.

How will Iran respond?

At this point Iran is retaliating by striking US military bases in the area and Israel, and it's not targeting the regional energy infrastructure, and it's not targeting energy flows through the Strait of Hormuz.

During this early phase of the war, Iran is likely primarily concerned about the safety of its leaders and ensuring regime succession in case the key figures are terminated. In addition, the regime is likely monitoring the internal situation to ensure that there is no internal rebellion.

Phase Two could be more brutal

So, that's the current situation - if the Phase One accomplishes regime change in Iran, one way or another, the operation ends. The Phase One could last a few weeks, with the targeted end before Trump visits China in late March.

If Phase One is unsuccessful in regime change, Phase Two could be more brutal. For the US, there is no turning back anymore; the war has started.

Phase Two might involve strikes on Iranian energy infrastructure and could even involve some "boots on the ground."

Iran is likely to retaliate by also targeting US economic interests, striking regional energy infrastructure, and attempting to close the Strait of Hormuz. The Iranian regime in this situation could become more desperate and thus more dangerous.

Ultimately, the US will prevail. However, Phase Three could involve other countries and regions. How will China respond? How will Russia respond? The longer this war lasts, the more dangerous it becomes for global stability.

Impact on the financial markets

Phase One of Operation Epic Fury is mostly benign for the financial markets. Neither side is currently targeting the regional energy infrastructure, and the flow of oil continues through the Strait of Hormuz.

Financial markets are strictly concerned about the price of oil and the implications of inflationary expectations and, thus, the central bank policy. At this point, it seems like the US wants to avoid the oil price spike, given the affordability issues leading into the midterm elections.

The immediate effect will likely be Flight to Safety (based on current information):

  • The US Dollar (DXY) is likely to rise.
  • Treasury Bonds are likely to rise with the 10Y yield (US10Y) falling towards 3.75%.
  • Gold (GLD) could also rise, although the price of Gold already reflects the worst scenario.
  • Oil (USO) price to stay elevated, likely around $70, but the spike is not likely in this phase.
  • The stock market (SP500) could open lower, but the bounce is likely; in fact, lower interest rates could be positive for the stock market, and this could be a temporary distraction from the real issues, like the private credit issue and the AI bubble burst.

However, the situation is fluid, and it could change. Specifically, we could have a quick resolution in Iran before the markets even open on Monday, and that could cause a huge relief rally in the S&P 500 as VIX (VIX) falls.

The problems for the financial markets will start to emerge as the war drags on towards Phase Two - that's when the oil price spikes well above $100, causing a global recession, with a major correction of 30-35% in the stock market.

At this point it is difficult to predict; the news is flowing in. At the time of writing, this news came in. There will be more clarity by Monday, but the playbook is clear.

Financial markets will hope that this news is correct and that Operation Epic Fury concludes quickly, which is also the hope of all civilians, as it would greatly reduce the civilian casualties on all sides.

Introduction

President Trump finally announced major combat operations in Iran, and my intention with this article is to address the prospects and consequences for investments.

Note: Before starting to read this article, it is important to emphasize that this author regrets this humanitarian tragedy; however, it is his duty to list the implications for investments for his readers.

The United States and Israel carried out a coordinated attack on Iran early Saturday morning. In the image below you can see where the attacks on Iran take place.

Context

This is completely different from the case in Venezuela. Iran produces approximately 3.3 million barrels of oil per day despite international sanctions. It is worth noting that more than 80% of exports go to China.

Another intriguing point is location, given that the Strait of Hormuz, responsible for the passage of 20% of global oil, is between Iran and Oman. There were around 13 million barrels of crude oil per day transiting the Strait in 2025.

Therefore, the short-term impact I expect is oil appreciation (5% to 10%) and defense actions. On the other hand, assets that are expected to fall will be American and global stocks (1% to 2%) and, to a greater extent, cryptocurrencies (3% to 10%). At this moment, on decentralized exchanges, oil rose 8%, gold rose 4%, and the Nasdaq fell more than 1%.

This event consolidates my investment theses in oil ETFs. This recommendation is putting a lot of profit in the pockets of investors who followed the recommendation.

But the big question now is whether the Iranian regime will be deposed. It also remains to be seen whether the strait and oil production will remain unscathed. Given the facts, let's analyze the pessimistic scenario and the optimistic scenario.

Pessimistic Scenario

The event has a remote chance of causing an energy crisis in the world, in my opinion. If this happens, the logical tendency is for oil to rise in value, and in this scenario, net oil-exporting countries can be safe havens for investments, in my opinion.

One example is Brazil. The country is a net oil exporter, and it is worth noting that my portfolio of recommended stocks for 2026 has a mix of American stocks and Brazilian stocks, and the portfolio easily beats the S&P 500 year-to-date.

Optimistic Scenario

In the optimistic scenario, the Trump administration has created a scenario in which the Iranian regime is replaced by a more stable leadership led by the Iranian people. It is worth remembering that sanctions on Iran were introduced in 2017, when the country was producing just over 4.1 million barrels per day, and currently production is 3.1 million barrels per day.

This means that there has been a significant reduction, and if there is greater alignment with the US and not with OPEC, the increase in production could result in a drop in oil prices in the medium term, possibly as early as the second half of this year.

The Bottom Line

Therefore, although the price of oil may rise in the short term, in the medium term, as supply increases, the equilibrium price could easily fall. Therefore, the outlook for the second half of 2026 would be a disinflationary effect, which would boost global stock markets.

In general, events of this type should not be reasons for a person to sell their investments. At these moments, it is important to remember why you purchased your assets and stick to your investment thesis. I remain convinced of all my investment theses regardless of this event.

data.title: Operation Epic Fury: I Expect A Stock Market Relief Rally
data.description:
After multiple attempts to negotiate over Iran's nuclear enrichment program and some other concerns, President Trump announced that the United States and Israel have launched "Operation Epic Fury" against Iran. The initial wave of this operation seems to have focused on taking out Iranian missile launchers and potentially some of the Iranian leadership. Obviously, this is a major geopolitical event that could trigger significant and immediate shockwaves across the financial markets. Because this operation was launched late on a Friday evening (February 27th) and escalated over Saturday, and most of the global financial markets are closed, we have not seen the visible impacts on stocks. I have seen some social media posts suggesting the stock market could be due for a sharp plunge when markets reopen; however, I see some counterpoints to this argument. With all this in mind, let's examine the potential implications for various financial assets:

Note: I’m mindful of the heavy human and political weight of current events, but for the purpose of this piece, I’m keeping the focus strictly on the market side of things. The goal here is to provide a clear-eyed look at the economic impacts, independent of the broader headlines.

The Initial Strike

The initial strike's occurrence in Iran during daylight hours was surprising. This might have been due to strategic plans, as some reports suggest that Israel knew that some Iranian leadership was gathered at one location. It also occurred just shortly after negotiation talks with Iran took place in Geneva. All of this might have caught Iran's regime off guard in terms of the timing of a potential attack.

Tomahawk missiles, which are made by RTX Corporation (RTX), appear to have been used extensively in this initial wave, and some of the other targets in Iran reportedly included the locations of the Ministry of Intelligence, the Ministry of Defense, and the Presidential Institution. It is also said to have targeted senior Iranian leadership, including high-ranking political officials and military commanders. Nuclear-sensitive sites such as the Atomic Energy Organization headquarters in Tehran and military complexes and facilities in Isfahan and Qom were also targeted. Iran's missile industry near Tabriz and multiple launch sites across Iran were also targeted. The Iranian Navy and air defense systems were also struck by Operation Epic Fury.

Iran Retaliates

Iran launched retaliatory attacks using drones and missiles against Israel and U.S. bases in the Middle East. It is not surprising to see that Iran has launched an attack on Israel and sirens have been blaring in Tel Aviv; however, Israel's strong missile defenses appear to be taking down most of the incoming projectiles, and for now it seems that only very limited damage has been sustained. It's worth noting that even though Saudi Arabia did not allow the U.S. to use bases in that country for Operation Epic Fury, Iran has launched attacks on this and other Arab nations. This could be a major miscalculation on the part of Iran, because Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries might retaliate for this aggression. I see Iran's attacks on Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, and Kuwait as a sign of desperation—potentially the final acts of a regime that has little to lose because it knows its days are likely numbered.

Initial Reaction From Financial Markets

Even though most financial markets were closed for the weekend, there were some hints of a risk-off reaction from Bitcoin, which initially plunged after the attacks were launched. However, Bitcoin has recovered almost all of its losses and is nearly unchanged. Futures for gold and the U.S. Dollar also were impacted initially as potential safe haven assets; however, I believe that if Iran is unable to show more of a military response, the response could be muted by the time the stock market opens next week.

An Energy Shock?

Oil prices will be a key concern. The major risk is if Iran attempts to partially or completely close the Strait of Hormuz, through which about 20% of the world's oil passes. Some analysts suggest that a sustained blockade of this key waterway could cause oil prices to surge towards $120 to $150 per barrel. However, it seems unlikely that Iran could close this waterway for long, if at all. Doing so would devastate its own economy because it could no longer ship oil out, thereby forfeiting a major revenue source for the Iranian regime. Many other countries, including Iranian allies like China, are said to also oppose the closure of this waterway for their own economic reasons.

Kharg Island handles roughly 90% of Iran's crude oil exports, making this another key concern. An attack on or blockade of Kharg Island could push up oil prices. The biggest potential risks for financial markets are a surge in oil prices due to the closure of the Strait of Hormuz or damage to oil facilities on Kharg Island. There are reports that the U.S. or Israel could attempt to seize control of Kharg Island to choke off Iran's primary source of oil revenues.

Another risk factor to consider is whether Iran attacks oil facilities in neighboring countries. This could have significant implications for oil prices and the financial markets. It also remains to be seen if Iranian allies like Hezbollah will enter this war in a major way.

Stock Market Implications

Major stock market indexes plunged on Friday, February 27th, due to AI disruption concerns and a hotter-than-expected inflation report. I would also add that the U.S. military buildup that occurred in the Middle East over the past several weeks made it clear that an attack on Iran could come soon, especially since the recent negotiations in Geneva concluded without any immediate solutions. This suggests that the stock market may have already priced in some type of military action, and many expected it could come this weekend since the U.S. military buildup appeared complete. The fear of an imminent attack may have also contributed to stock market losses on Friday.

If the oil market remains stable over this weekend because none of the worst-case scenarios, such as a closure of the Strait of Hormuz, occur, I believe the stock market could react positively to Operation Epic Fury, even though this is in contrast to some of the more fearful posts I see on social media. As shown below, the market has been stuck in a trading range; therefore, better-than-feared news regarding Iran could spark a relief rally in the coming days.

Here's My Strategy

Iran's initial response appears weak. If the regime collapses and the Iranian people take control of the government, this could be a very positive event for many financial assets. It is still early, and a lot could still happen. I believe the key for investors is if oil supplies remain stable. If this occurs, I do not expect a big negative reaction from the stock market, and instead I anticipate a potential relief rally. If oil prices surge due to attacks on Middle Eastern energy facilities or if the Strait of Hormuz is closed, the market could plunge. I would use this as a buying opportunity in many stocks. Airlines, cruise lines, and transportation stocks could be among the hardest-hit sectors. I would buy weakness on any major pullbacks in these sectors. I would also consider buying the recent weakness in stocks like Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT).

In Summary

There is a lot going on, and this is not over, but the initial results of this strike on Iran do not suggest a worst-case scenario for oil prices or the financial markets. I would watch Bitcoin prices over the weekend as a proxy for risk assets and then futures on Sunday night to prepare for what might come for investors next week. As things stand now, I expect a relief rally for stocks, but this could change if matters escalate. However, I would use any sharp market pullback as a potential buying opportunity.

data.title: Iran Escalation Shock Triggers Risk-Off Move To USD And Gold, Oil, Defense And Aerospace Win
data.description:
President Trump has confirmed that major combat operations in Iran have started in coordination with Israel. In this report, I discuss how this may affect the global markets with attention to energy, freight and logistics, airlines, crypto, aerospace, and defense.

Note: War often comes with an unmeasurable amount of human tragedy and a fair bit of geopolitics. While I am cognizant of these factors, this report does not intend to discuss either the human tragedy or the politics behind the most recent combat action but aims to provide qualitative analysis of its impacts on markets, crypto(currencies), and commodities.

The Strikes In Iran Hardly Come As A Surprise

In my view, the strikes hardly come as a surprise, as President Trump previously already communicated that he had the USS Gerald R. Ford in the region. It is the second aircraft carrier that has been deployed to the Middle East along with its strike group. The carrier arrived at the Israeli coast yesterday. So, the fact that strikes occurred today is not surprising. We also note that in the weeks prior, a large movement of fighter jets, military cargo airplanes, civil cargo airplanes, and tankers occurred. These airplanes were initially placed in Sofia (Bulgaria) and Crete. I live roughly 300 km away from Sofia in Bucharest and already noticed increased military flight activity over the past days. From my time living in Sibiu (the NATO Headquarters Multinational Corps Southeast) and the war in Ukraine, I also know that increased military flight activity usually is a prelude to an attack.

The strikes currently are relatively contained. Iran has responded with targeting assets in countries in the Middle East, but for the time being we are not seeing a full-blown air or ground attack.

Risk Off Mode To Hurt Equities And Crypto

Markets already have been in a relatively strong risk-off mode, but my expectation is that this will intensify. Higher risk assets such as cryptocurrencies will be under pressure. At the time of writing, Bitcoin (BTC-USD) has fallen 1.7%, but we note that following the attack, Bitcoin prices had fallen as much as 3.5%. Year-to-date, Bitcoin is down more than 25%, so the attacks in Iran are likely to pressure sentiment further. Ethereum (ETH-USD) has fallen in line with Bitcoin. So, overall, among the two major cryptocurrencies, we see a modestly lower price.

Generally, equity markets (QQQ, SP500, SPYSPY, DJI) are expected also to be under pressure as investors process the attacks that already happened and weigh the uncertainty ahead, as we are not seeing a full blown escalation yet. For equity markets, the picture is not necessarily fully negative or positive. The initial reaction will more than likely be negative, but from there the technical picture (holding key support levels) is going to matter as well as how the conflict evolves. If a response from Iran is in some way unmeasured or escalatory, then we will see an acceleration in the rotation out of stocks towards safer assets.

Oil Companies Set To Benefit

Oil companies such as Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) are likely set to benefit as oil prices head higher, and even in the short term, some money may flow into oil related equities driven by sentiment. Companies that are not set to benefit are midstream companies, which derive most of their income from commodity-neutral pricing schemes. We do note that demand for oil remains weak. So, the fluctuations in oil prices and the benefit that oil companies can derive from that are largely going to depend on the ability of oil shippers to supply. A more long-lived opportunity would present itself for higher oil prices and stock prices for oil companies if critical oil production and transportation infrastructure were being destroyed. However, we also note that an escalation could affect demand for oil due to weaker macroeconomic growth, and many countries can actually produce more barrels than they are currently doing. So, it would take a large scale evaporation of oil production and transportation capability to spark a major imbalance between supply and demand.

Freight And Logistics: A Mixed Picture

For freight and logistics companies, the picture is overall a mixed one. Oil tanker companies are likely set to benefit. The reason is that a closure of the strait does not reduce demand for oil, but it does mean many tankers will be locked in their place in the Persian Gulf. The Fujairah pipeline in the UAE and the East-West Crude Oil Pipeline connecting the Saudi eastern oil fields to the Red Sea port have limited capacity. Combined, these pipelines could process just 34% of the flow of barrels through the Strait of Hormuz. So, we are likely going to see some spike in oil transportation rates. War risk insurance premiums are likely going to increase, but that also drives shippers to not enter the strait and explore other opportunities that drive longer voyages, creating a higher ton-mile effect. Putting it simply, the usable fleet shrinks as fear makes shipping scarce, while effective capacity is being reduced through longer voyages as well.

For general trade, we note there is only a positive effect if there is a spillover of the conflict to other key routes such as the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, or Bab-el-Mandeb. These are key to the access to the Suez Canal. If the Suez Canal is inaccessible, it means longer voyages are required, meaning that effective capacity is lowered and freight rates increase. Absent a conflict spillover, the global cargo shippers are going to see just the higher cost effect of oil as a fuel. This indirectly increases shipping rates to pass through higher operational costs but also may result in route optimization, network redesign, and slow steaming to save fuel. All of these could disrupt existing global trade routes and capacity and increase rates.

Airlines Do Not Do Well On Geopolitical Tension And War

Airlines are the clear loser in this. Airline stocks are volatile and react to disruptions fast. At the time of writing, the airports of Doha, Dubai, and Abu Dhabi are among the airports that are closed. United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL), with European airlines such as Lufthansa (DLAKF), Air France-KLM (AFRAF), and British Airways (ICAGY) are no longer flying to the Middle East. It creates missed revenues, and recalibrating capacity may weaken unit revenues in other markets. So, there is an immediate cost and revenue effect that is likely modest, but the longer this takes, the more the missed revenues and profits compound and the higher the risk that airlines will have to deploy capacity elsewhere and weaken fare prices in those markets.

Cargo freight rates may increase as airlines avoid the Middle East, and the same holds for passenger airlines, but the effect for passenger airlines is much less positive than it could be for cargo airlines.

Aerospace and Defense Is The Clear Winner

The clear winner, more than likely in terms of sentiment, is aerospace and defense. When tension increases, aerospace and defense companies perform well. We are already seeing that there is an aerospace and defense supercycle, and while aerospace and defense companies are not going to be winning new contracts tomorrow, sentiment is likely to improve for investment in aerospace and defense, and the recent events support a prolonged elevation of defense budgets.

Looking at the flight radar, there are tens and maybe hundreds of airplanes we do not see. However, we see an Airbus (EADSF) refueling airplane airborne as well as an Airbus tactical transport airplane. Furthermore, we see an MQ-9 Reaper airborne and a Boeing (BA) F-15 with its transponder turned on. Furthermore, I am aware of flight activity for the C-5, F-35 and F-22 built by Lockheed Martin (LMT) and the E-3, P-8A, C-17A, KC-135 and KC-46A by Boeing. So, Boeing and Lockheed Martin provide a lot of air power.

Furthermore, there are strike carrier groups for the Abraham Lincoln and Gerald R Ford aircraft carriers built by Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) consisting of the guided-missile destroyers of the Arleigh Burke class built by HII and General Dynamics and littoral combat ships built by Austal (AUTLF) and Fincantieri (FNCNF).

On those ships, there likely will be F-35 and F/A-18 fighter jets, helicopters and tactical aircraft and ships and aircraft will be equipped with missiles. Stitching all of that together is a layer of intelligence equipment. So, we are looking at a broad-based deployment from ships, fighter jets, helicopters, intelligence airplanes, tankers, missiles, missile defense and radars. It makes it a broad-based deployment of US made equipment, which I believe will draw investor attention. Another company that likely will see positive attention is Elbit Systems. Elbit is an Israeli company and given that Israel is involved in the combat action I do expect it to be one of the stocks in focus.

So, while there will not be any fundamental support for higher stock prices for aerospace and defense companies we will likely see improved sentiment and support for higher defense budgets over the longer-term.

Commodity Prices: Oil Shock And Gold As Safe Haven

For commodity prices, the expectation is that those will increase. Given the importance of the Middle East for oil production, oil is likely to spike. We already note that Brent Futures (CO1:COM) are up 2.9%. So, we are looking at the Strait of Hormuz effect as this is a crucial waterway for global oil trade. The narrow passage between Iran and Oman is set to become the literal bottleneck for global oil trade. Daily, around 20-21 million barrels pass through this strait, and it is highly likely that there will be disruptions. We are already seeing reports of oil and gas majors and traders suspending shipments via Hormuz. So, oil and gas will head up, and a further escalation of the conflict or a prolonged war would further increase those prices limited by development of demand in the macroeconomic picture.

As the risk off sentiment is likely to intensify, we will see a spike in gold prices. So, Gold is once again going to fulfill its role of safe haven, attracting liquidity exiting the equity and cryptocurrency markets.

USD Likely To Strengthen

As investors liquidate positions and we note that buying safe-haven assets and oil is usually dollar-denominated, we are likely going to see the USD strengthen. Quite often we see that investors view the power position that the US has as a favor that is being done to the world. That is, however, not fully the case. The power projection, both politically and militarily, also serves as a strengthening mechanism for the US Dollar and I believe we will see this in play as well.

Overview Of Impacts Of Combat Action In Iran

Ideally, we would be able to provide a playbook on which parts of the markets will win and which ones will lose. The reality, however, is that there currently is a lot of uncertainty. We do not know whether military actions have been successful and the duration of military action and responses. So, the duration and military impact and consequences for the region and world are not known at this point in time. So, we are only able to map, the near-term expected impacts. I have done that in the diagram below.

What we see is that military action brings several axes along sentiment and rotation of funds can take place. These axes are:

  • Disruption in logistics affecting flights and shipping capacity
  • Higher oil prices
  • Risk sentiment recalibration

Higher oil prices are beneficial for oil companies and there likely will also be some risk-on sentiment for oil and gas companies.

Risk sentiment recalibration currently is expected to drive the majority of the market movements. Risk off sentiment will negatively affect cryptocurrencies, equity markets and airlines while USD and Gold are likely to strengthen. Risk-on sentiment for now is likely only expected to strongly benefit aerospace and defense.

Disruptions due to air space closures are a negative for airlines while the combination of limited shipping capacity available and war risk premiums will benefit oil shippers. Global maritime has a mixed set of inputs. Rerouting and conflict spillover would limit available shipping capacity, which is a positive. However, higher oil prices drive up operational costs.

Conclusion: First Reaction Is Sentiment Drive

The first reaction in the markets will be driven by risk sentiment calibration. For the equity market, the extent of declines is going to be determined by holding key technical support levels. Beyond that, the duration and effect of the military action are going to become increasingly more dominant to give the market direction.
